messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 46 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Improving the Detection of Small Oriented Objects in Aerial Images

Paper Abstract: Abstract Small oriented objects that represent tiny pixel-area in large-scale aerial images are difficult to detect due to their size and orientation. Existing oriented aerial detectors have shown promising results but are mainly focused on orientation modeling with less regard to the size of the objects. In this work, we proposed a method to accurately detect small oriented objects in aerial images by enhancing the classification and regression tasks of the oriented object detection model. We designed the Attention-Points Network consisting of two losses: Guided-Attention Loss (GALoss) and Box-Points Loss (BPLoss). GALoss uses an instance segmentation mask as ground-truth to learn the attention features needed to improve the detection of small objects. These attention features are then used to predict box points for BPLoss, which determines the pointsâ€™ position relative to the target oriented bounding box. Experimental results show the effectiveness of our Attention-Points Network on a standard oriented aerial dataset with small object instances (DOTA-v1.5) and on a maritime-related dataset (HRSC2016). The code is publicly available111https://github.com/chandlerbing65nm/APDetection..

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 46 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 46"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Neural machine translation by jointly learning to align and translate",
        "Cascade r-cnn: Delving into high quality object detection",
        "Dual-modality vehicle anomaly detection via bilateral trajectory tracing",
        "Hybrid task cascade for instance segmentation",
        "MMDetection: Open mmlab detection toolbox and benchmark",
        "PIoU Loss: Towards Accurate Oriented Object Detection in Complex Environments",
        "Learning roi transformer for oriented object detection in aerial images",
        "Object detection in aerial images: A large-scale benchmark and challenges",
        "Pascal visual object classes challenge 2007 (voc2007) complete dataset",
        "The PASCAL Visual Object Classes Challenge 2012 (VOC2012) Results",
        "Align Deep Features for Oriented Object Detection",
        "ReDet: A Rotation-equivariant Detector for Aerial Object Detection",
        "Mask r-cnn",
        "Deep Residual Learning for Image Recognition",
        "R2cnn: Rotational region cnn for orientation robust scene text detection",
        "Oriented reppoints for aerial object detection",
        "Feature pyramid networks for object detection",
        "Focal Loss for Dense Object Detection",
        "Mogface: Towards a deeper appreciation on face detection",
        "A high resolution optical satellite image dataset for ship recognition and some new baselines",
        "Arbitrary-oriented scene text detection via rotation proposals",
        "Dynamic anchor learning for arbitrary-oriented object detection",
        "Mask-guided attention network for occluded pedestrian detection",
        "Rsdet++: Point-based modulated loss for more accurate rotated object detection",
        "Faster R-CNN: Towards Real-Time Object Detection with Region Proposal Networks",
        "FCOS: Fully convolutional one-stage object detection",
        "Selective search for object recognition",
        "Seadronessee: A maritime benchmark for detecting humans in open water",
        "Learning maritime obstacle detection from weak annotations by scaffolding",
        "Hla-face: Joint high-low adaptation for low light face detection",
        "Non-local Neural Networks",
        "A multi-camera vehicle tracking system based on city-scale vehicle re-id and spatial-temporal information",
        "DOTA : A Large-scale Dataset for Object Detection in Aerial Images",
        "Oriented R-CNN for Object Detection",
        "Gliding Vertex on the Horizontal Bounding Box for Multi-Oriented Object Detection",
        "Dense label encoding for boundary discontinuity free rotation detection",
        "R3Det: Refined Single-Stage Detector with Feature Refinement for Rotating Object",
        "Rethinking Rotated Object Detection with Gaussian Wasserstein Distance Loss",
        "SCRDet: Towards more robust detection for small, cluttered and rotated objects",
        "Learning High-Precision Bounding Box for Rotated Object Detection via Kullback-Leibler Divergence",
        "Detecting rotated objects as gaussian distributions and its 3-d generalization",
        "Alpharotate: A rotation detection benchmark using tensorflow",
        "The kfiou loss for rotated object detection",
        "Oriented object detection in aerial images with box boundary-aware vectors",
        "An Image is Worth 16x16 Words: Transformers for Image Recognition at Scale",
        "Efficient attention: Attention with linear complexities"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 46 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Improving the Detection of Small Oriented Objects in Aerial Images, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
